Subunit a is the least understood of the three subunits that compose the F0 sector in theEscherichia coli F0F1 ATP synthase. In this study, we have substituted Cys into predicted extramembranous loops of the protein and used chemical modification to obtain topographical information on the folding of subunit a. The extent of labeling of the substituted Cys residues by fluorescein-5′-maleimide was determined. The localization of reactive Cys residues was inferred from differences in the extent of labeling in inside out and right side out membrane vesicles. The NH2-terminal segment of subunit a was localized to the outside (periplasmic) surface and the COOH terminus to the cytoplasmic surface by these procedures. Loop residues in two periplasmic extramembranous loops and in two cytoplasmic extramembranous loops were also localized. The localization of two cytoplasmic Cys residues was confirmed by using 4-acetamido-4′-maleimidylstilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid to block fluorescein-5′-maleimide labeling. From the localization of the Cys residues, a model for the topography is proposed that consists of five transmembrane segments with the NH2 terminus periplasmic and the COOH terminus cytoplasmic. The positions of second site suppressors, including several isolated here to the nonfunctional E219C and H245C substitutions, provide support for the topographical model proposed. Subunit a is the least understood of the three subunits that compose the F0 sector in theEscherichia coli F0F1 ATP synthase. In this study, we have substituted Cys into predicted extramembranous loops of the protein and used chemical modification to obtain topographical information on the folding of subunit a. The extent of labeling of the substituted Cys residues by fluorescein-5′-maleimide was determined. The localization of reactive Cys residues was inferred from differences in the extent of labeling in inside out and right side out membrane vesicles. The NH2-terminal segment of subunit a was localized to the outside (periplasmic) surface and the COOH terminus to the cytoplasmic surface by these procedures. Loop residues in two periplasmic extramembranous loops and in two cytoplasmic extramembranous loops were also localized. The localization of two cytoplasmic Cys residues was confirmed by using 4-acetamido-4′-maleimidylstilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid to block fluorescein-5′-maleimide labeling. From the localization of the Cys residues, a model for the topography is proposed that consists of five transmembrane segments with the NH2 terminus periplasmic and the COOH terminus cytoplasmic. The positions of second site suppressors, including several isolated here to the nonfunctional E219C and H245C substitutions, provide support for the topographical model proposed. H+-transporting F1F0 ATP synthases consist of two structurally and functionally distinct sectors termed F1 and F0 (1Senior A.E. Physiol. Rev. 1989; 68: 177-231Crossref Scopus (452) Google Scholar). The F1 sector lies at the surface of the membrane and in Escherichia coliconsists of five subunits in aα 3 β 3 γ 1 δ 1 ε 1stoichiometry. The F0 sector spans the membrane and inE. coli consists of three subunits in an a1b2c10 + 1 stoichiometry (2Fillingame R.H. Kurlwich T.A. The Bacteria. 12. Academic Press, Inc., New York1990: 345-391Google Scholar). In the intact enzyme, ATP synthesis or hydrolysis takes place in the F1 sector and is coupled to active H+ transport through the F0 sector. Structurally similar F0F1 ATP synthases are present in mitochondria, chloroplasts, and most other eubacteria (1Senior A.E. Physiol. Rev. 1989; 68: 177-231Crossref Scopus (452) Google Scholar). The structure of theα 3 β 3 γ 1part of the bovine mitochondrial F1 sector has been solved by x-ray crystallography (3Abrahams J.P. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2715) Google Scholar). Structures of major parts of the isolatedδ and ε subunits of the E. colienzyme have been solved by NMR (4Wilkens S. Dunn S.D. Chandler J. Dahlquist F.W. Capaldi R.A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1997; 4: 198-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 5Wilkens S. Dahlquist F.W. McIntosh L.P. Donaldson L.W. Capaldi R.A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1995; 2: 961-967Crossref PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar). In contrast to the F1 sector, there is very little structural information available on the F0 sector. The structure of portions of monomeric subunit c in an organic solvent mixture has been solved by NMR (6Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 665-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 7Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1635-1645Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). In the solvent system used, subunit c folds as a hairpin of two α-helices. Biochemical and genetic evidence suggests that the structure determined by NMR mimics the structure of the subunit in the membrane (8Fillingame R.H. J. Exp. Biol. 1997; 200: 217-224Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Subunit c contains an Asp residue in the middle of the second transmembrane helix, which functions as the key H+ binding site in the proton conduction pathway through F0 (8Fillingame R.H. J. Exp. Biol. 1997; 200: 217-224Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Deckers-Hebestreit G. Altendorf K. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1996; 50: 824-971Crossref Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 10Nakamoto R.K. J. Membr. Biol. 1996; 151: 101-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Subunit b consists of an NH2-terminal transmembrane helix and a largely α-helical cytoplasmic domain that is responsible for binding F1 (9Deckers-Hebestreit G. Altendorf K. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1996; 50: 824-971Crossref Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 10Nakamoto R.K. J. Membr. Biol. 1996; 151: 101-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Subunit a is a very hydrophobic 30-kDa protein of 271 residues that is thought to span the membrane multiple times (2Fillingame R.H. Kurlwich T.A. The Bacteria. 12. Academic Press, Inc., New York1990: 345-391Google Scholar). It is thought to function with subunit c in ATPase-coupled proton translocation (11Hatch P.L. Cox G.B. Howitt S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 29407-29412Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 12Valiyaveetil F. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32635-32641Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). There have been no structural studies reported on subunit a. A number of topographical models, consisting of 4–7 transmembrane helices have been proposed based on hydropathy plots (2Fillingame R.H. Kurlwich T.A. The Bacteria. 12. Academic Press, Inc., New York1990: 345-391Google Scholar), although topographical models consisting of five or six transmembrane helices are now commonly favored (11Hatch P.L. Cox G.B. Howitt S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 29407-29412Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 13Vik S.B. Dao N.N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1140: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Studies on the topography of the subunit using proteases, gene fusions, or sequence-specific antibodies have yielded contradictory results (14Hoppe J. Friedl P. Schairer H.U. Sebald W. von Meyenberg K. Jorgensen B.B. EMBO J. 1983; 2: 105-110Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 15Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Lewis M.J. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3482-3489Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Bjorbaek C. Foersom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 18Yamada H. Moriyama Y. Maeda M. Futai M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 34-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). Genetic introduction of Cys and chemical labeling has been used to obtain topographical information on several membrane proteins,e.g. MotA (19Zhou J. Fazzio R.T. Blair D.F. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 251: 237-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar), P-glycoprotein (20Loo T. Clark D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 843-848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar), and Tn10-TetA transport protein (21Kimura T. Ohnuma M. Sawai T. Yamaguchi A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 580-585Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar), and we have applied that strategy here to subunit a. In this approach, Cys residues are introduced at a number of sites predicted to fall in loops outside the membrane and accessibility of these Cys to sulfydryl-directed reagents determined with membrane vesicles of opposite sidedness. From the extent of labeling in differently oriented vesicles, the cellular localization of the Cys residues can be inferred. Sufficient Cys residues have been topographically localized in subunit a by this approach to provide a topographical model. Second site suppressors can provide hints about the interacting parts of a protein and, for a membrane protein, suggest possible topographical models. It has previously been demonstrated that the Glu219 and His245 residues of subunit a are not essential for function (12Valiyaveetil F. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32635-32641Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar, 22Hartzog P.E. Cain B.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32313-32317Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). There are, however, narrow limits on the residues that can be substituted at either position with retention of function. We show here that Cys is not tolerated at either of these positions. Second site suppressors to the nonfunctional E219C and H245C mutations have been isolated. The positions of these second site suppressors and of other suppressor pairs previously described in the literature are easily interpreted by the topographical model derived from Cys reactivity. For the introduction of a His6 tag following residue 269 in subunit a, a BglII site was initially introduced at the COOH terminus of the uncB gene (which encodes subunit a). An oligonucleotide, GGTAAATTAAAGATCTTCAGACG, was synthesized, which corresponds to nucleotides 1823–1845 1The unc DNA numbering system corresponds to that used by Walker et al. (23Walker J.E. Saraste M. Gay J.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1984; 768: 164-200Crossref PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar). of the wild typeuncB gene, except for the underlined nucleotides, which result in the introduction of a BglII site. The mutations were incorporated into a PCR 2The abbreviations used are: PCR, polymerase chain reaction; ISO, stripped inside out membrane vesicles; RSO, right side out membrane vesicles; FM, fluorescein 5-maleimide; ACMA, 9-amino-6-chloro-2-methoxyacridine; AMS, 4-acetamido-4′-maleimidylstilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid, disodium salt; TCEP, Tris-(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride; Tricine,N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine. fragment using the megaprimer method (24Barik S. Trower M.K. Methods in Molecular Biology. 57. Humana Press Inc., Totowa, NJ1996: 203-215Google Scholar). The megaprimer method involves the use of a mutant primer and two wild type primers. Primers TGCTGCCGTACATTGCT and CACAGCACAATGCCTCT, which initiate DNA synthesis at nucleotides 1397 and 2189, respectively, were used as the wild type primers. The DNA fragment obtained from the PCR protocol was cloned between the PstI(1565) and AvaI(1976) sites in plasmid pCP1200, resulting in plasmid pVF172. Plasmid pCP1200 contains the HindIII(870) to AvaI(1976) fragment ofunc DNA cloned between these sites in plasmid pBR322 (25Paule C.R. Fillingame R.H. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1989; 274: 270-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). The presence of the BglII site in the plasmid pVF172 was confirmed by restriction digests and DNA sequencing. The His6 tag at the COOH terminus was introduced by digesting plasmid pVF172 with BglII and ligating with the following synthetic DNA fragment. GATCATCATCATCATCATCATTAATAGTAGTAGTAGTAGTAATTCTAGSEQUENCE 1 This resulted in plasmid pVF196. The presence of the Asp-His6 tag and stop codon following the Glu269 codon was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Cys substitutions were introduced by the megaprimer method using a synthetic oligonucleotide, which contained the desired codon change, and two wild type primers. The DNA fragment resulting from the megaprimer mutagenesis protocol was cloned into the plasmid pVF196 using appropriate restriction sites. For example, the E131C mutation was constructed using the oligonucleotide GCCGTACATTGCTTGCCATGTACTGGGTCT, which corresponds to nucleotides 1401–1430 of the wild type uncB gene except that the E131 codon is substituted by TGC (underlined), which encodes Cys. Primers TTCTTCTCGGTGGTGCT and CTGGTTTGGACAGCAGG, which initiate DNA synthesis at nucleotides 1162 and 1636, respectively, were used as the wild type primers. The resulting PCR fragment was cloned between the NcoI(1305) and PstI(1565) sites in plasmid pVF196. The S202C, N214C, and I223C mutations were provided by Dr. W. Jiang (University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI) on a pDF163-like plasmid (26Fraga D. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6797-6803Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Plasmid pDF163 contains the HindIII(870) toSphI(3216) fragment of unc DNA cloned between these sites in plasmid pBR322. The mutations were transferred to a pVF196-like plasmid by subcloning the BamHI fragment from the corresponding pDF163 derivative into the BamHI sites in pVF196. The presence of the Cys substitution in the resulting plasmids was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Cells were grown in M63 minimal medium containing 0.6% glucose supplemented with 2 mg/liter thiamine, 0.2 mm uracil, 0.2 mml-arginine, 0.02 mm dihydrobenzoic acid supplemented with 10% LB medium (27Miller J.H. A Short Course in Bacterial Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1992Google Scholar). Ampicillin, when needed, was added to a final concentration of 0.1 mg/ml. Cells were grown to late logarithmic phase and harvested for preparation of inside out (ISO) and right side out (RSO) membrane vesicles. ISO membrane vesicles were prepared in TMDG buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm dithiothreitol, and 10% (v/v) glycerol) by rupture of cells using a French press (28Fillingame R.H. J. Bacteriol. 1975; 124: 870-883Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). ISO membrane vesicles used for the labeling experiments were stripped of F1 by incubation in TDEG buffer (1 mmTris-H2SO4, pH 8.0, 0.5 mm EDTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, and 10% (v/v) glycerol) for 30 min at 30 °C and then collected by centrifugation (28Fillingame R.H. J. Bacteriol. 1975; 124: 870-883Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). RSO membrane vesicles were prepared using a modification of the protocol of Kaback (29Kaback H.R. Methods Enzymol. 1971; 22: 99-120Crossref Scopus (552) Google Scholar). All of the centrifugation steps were performed at 4 °C. The centrifugal forces stated are the maximum for a given rotor. Briefly, cells were suspended in 0.03 m Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 30% sucrose, 10 mm EDTA, and 1 mm dithiothreitol and converted into spheroplasts by treatment with 20 μg/ml of lysozyme for 45 min at room temperature (22–24 °C). Spheroplasts were collected by centrifugation at 18,000 × g. The spheroplasts were suspended in 0.1 m phosphate buffer, pH 7.0, containing 30% sucrose, 25 mg/ml DNase I, 10 mm MgSO4, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and then lysed by a 1:100 dilution into 8 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.0, containing 1 mm dithiothreitol. After a 15-min incubation at 22–24 °C, EDTA was added to 10 mm, and after a further 15-min incubation, MgSO4 was added to 15 mm. The mixture was incubated for another 15 min, and the vesicles were collected by centrifugation at 18,000 ×g. Cell debris and unlysed spheroplasts present were removed by low speed centrifugation at 4000 × g. The right side out vesicles were finally harvested by centrifugation at 75,000 × g for 30 min. The vesicles were suspended in TMDG buffer and stored at −80 °C until use. RSO and ISO membrane vesicles were collected by centrifugation at 140,000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C and resuspended in one of two incubation buffers at a protein concentration of 15 mg/ml for RSO membrane vesicles and 10 mg/ml for ISO membrane vesicles. Approximately 1–2 mg of membrane protein was used for the labeling reaction. FM (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) was added from a stock solution prepared in dimethyl formamide and membranes were incubated at 30 °C. The volume of dimethyl formamide added never exceeded 1% of the reaction volume. The reaction was terminated by the addition of 1 m N-ethylmaleimide in ethanol to a final concentration of 30 mm. The membrane vesicles were solublized by the addition of SDS to a final concentration of 1%. The solution was diluted to approximately 1 mg/ml protein using His6 binding buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.3 m NaCl, 0.1% SDS). 40 μl of nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid-agarose beads (Qiagen Inc., Chatsworth, CA) were added, and the suspension was incubated with gentle shaking for 1 h at 22–24 °C. The beads were collected by centrifugation and washed twice with 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.3 m NaCl, 1% SDS. Proteins bound to the beads were eluted by boiling for 3 min at 100 °C in elution buffer (62.5 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.75, 20 mm EDTA, 2.5% β-mercaptoethanol, 10% glycerol, 2% SDS, 0.01% bromphenol blue). The eluted proteins were electrophoresed on a 12% polyacrylamide gel using the Tris-Tricine buffer system described by Schagger and von Jagow (30Schagger H. von Jagow G. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 166: 368-379Crossref PubMed Scopus (10408) Google Scholar). After electrophoresis, the unstained gel was photographed on a 300-nm transilluminator using a number 12 yellow filter (Tiffen, Hauppauge, NY) and Polaroid 665 film (F4.5, 2 min). The positive was developed by the manufacturer's instructions and scanned using a flat bed scanner linked to a Macintosh computer using OFOTO software (Lightsource Computer Images Inc.). The scan was quantitated using the public domain NIH Image program. 3Developed at the National Institutes of Health and available on the World Wide Web athttp://rsb.info.gov/nih-image. To determine the amount of subunit a present, the gel was stained using Coomassie Blue R-250 (31Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989: 18.55Google Scholar). The gel was dried, scanned, and quantitated as described above to obtain the amount of protein present. For isolation of revertants, the uncB deletion strain, VF245 (pyrE41, entA403, argH1, rpsL109, supE44, ΔuncB, recA56, srl::Tn10) (12Valiyaveetil F. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32635-32641Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar) was transformed with plasmids pVF156 and pVF158, which contain the E219C and H245C mutations, respectively, in the plasmid pDF163 (26Fraga D. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 6797-6803Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Overnight cultures of the transformants grown in LB medium were plated on succinate minimal agar plates and incubated at 37 °C. Revertant colonies were observed after incubation for 3–5 days. The revertants were purified by streaking for single colonies on succinate minimal medium plates. Protein concentration was determined using a modified Lowry protocol (28Fillingame R.H. J. Bacteriol. 1975; 124: 870-883Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). ATP-driven quenching experiments were performed with HMK buffer (10 mm HEPES-KOH, pH 7.5, 5 mm MgCl2, 0.3 m KCl) using ACMA at a final concentration of 0.3 μg/ml (12Valiyaveetil F. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 32635-32641Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). For easy purification of subunit a, a His6 tag was introduced at the COOH terminus. The uncB deletion strain, VF245, was transformed with either plasmid pVF196 (UncB(His) 6) or the UncB+control plasmid, pCP1200. The ability of the transformants to grow on succinate minimal plates was tested. A functional F0F1 ATP synthase is required for growth on succinate. The strain VF245/pVF196 was able to form colonies on succinate minimal medium plates, which were similar in size to colonies formed by VF245/pCP1200, indicating the presence of a functional ATP synthase. Further, membranes prepared from VF245/pVF196 and the wild type control strain (VF245/pCP1200) showed identical levels of ATP-driven quenching of ACMA fluorescence. The membranes also had similar ATPase activities and dicyclohexylcarbodiimide sensitivities. These experiments indicate that the His6 tag at the COOH terminus of subunit a has no effect on function of the enzyme, and therefore the His6 tag does not cause a significant perturbation of the structure of the subunit. A number of Cys residues were introduced into His6-tagged subunit a by PCR mutagenesis. The ΔuncB strain, VF245, was transformed with pCP1200-like plasmids containing the various Cys substitutions. For all Cys substitutions, the VF245 transformants grew on succinate, indicating minimal structural perturbation. The E196C, S202C, and M266C mutants did form single colonies that were slightly smaller than for wild type after 3 days of growth (i.e. 1.0, 1.5, and 1.5 mm, respectively, versus 2.0 mm for wild type). FM was used as the labeling reagent due to its high fluorescence extinction, which allowed detection of labeling of small amounts of protein. The localization of the Cys introduced into the subunit was determined by the difference in the extent of labeling by FM in ISO and RSO membrane vesicles. ISO vesicles were routinely stripped of F1 to enhance exposure of potential extramembranous Cys on the cytoplasmic face of the membrane. However, in no case did we find a reactive cytoplasmic Cys that was protected by F1 binding. In the final experimental protocol settled on here, the extent of labeling is described as the percentage of fluorescence intensity of a membrane sample labeled in the absence of SDS relative to the fluorescence intensity of the membrane sample labeled in the presence of 1% SDS. The fluorescence intensity was determined by scanning the photograph of the fluorescent gel. The fluorescence intensity of each membrane sample was standardized to the amount of protein present on the gel, which was determined by Coomassie staining, since the yield of His6-tagged protein recovered varied by approximately 20% from sample to sample. The increase in fluorescence intensity was nearly linear with the amount of protein applied to the gel over the fluorescence range used in the experiments below (Fig. 1). A shift in the mobility of the protein bands on SDS gels after labeling of Cys residues with FM or AMS has been reported previously for two proteins with molecular mass of 16 and 33 kDa, respectively (32Jones P.C. Harrison M.A. Kim Y. Finbow M.E. Findlay J.B.C. Biochem. J. 1995; 312: 739-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 33Krishnasastry M. Walker B. Braha O. Bayley H. FEBS Lett. 1994; 356: 66-71Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). In the case of subunit a, the shift in mobility was position-dependent and, of the mutants tested, was observed for the S3C-, S27C-, V71C-, and E131C-substituted proteins. The mobility shift observed with the E131C mutant protein upon labeling by FM is shown in Fig. 2. The shift was used to determine the fraction of the total subunit a that was modified by FM. In the presence of SDS, all of the subunit a present was labeled, as indicated by the complete shift in mobility of the subunit a band. The fraction of the subunit that was labeled in intact membrane vesicles was determined from the amount of protein present in the shifted versus the unshifted band. The fraction of the subunit in the shifted band (55% in Fig. 2) was very similar to the value obtained on comparing the standardized fluorescence intensity of the sample relative to the SDS control (59% in this experiment). 4As shown in Fig. 2, nearly all of the E131C subunit a in RSO vesicles was labeled by FM in the presence of SDS, and maximal labeling was seen in ISO vesicles as well (data not shown). When the normalized fluorescence intensities of other SDS controls were compared, no significant differences in the maximal labeling intensity were seen for ISO and RSO vesicles for all other mutants with the exception of S3C (see “S3C” under “Results”). Examples of other SDS controls are given in Fig. 5. For most residues, the labeling reaction was carried out with 1 mm FM for 5 min in TP buffer (0.1 m Tris, pH 8.8, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride). The high pH of the TP buffer helped to reduce the membrane permeability of FM by promoting ionization of the carboxyl group in the molecule. For residues that showed low reactivity to FM, e.g. E196C, reactions with 1 mm FM were carried out in TNP buffer (0.1m Tris, pH 8.0, 0.1 m NaCl, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) for 60 min to maximize the extent of reaction. Under both of the conditions used, labeling was specific to Cys, since no labeling was observed in wild type subunit a, which lacks Cys. The labeling characteristics of the various Cys residues are considered below. Cys residues introduced at both of these positions were highly reactive and easily labeled by 1 mmFM in both ISO and RSO membrane vesicles (TableI and Fig. 3). Greater than 90% labeling was observed in ISO vesicles relative to the SDS control, but RSO vesicles showed labeling approaching 60–70% of the SDS-treated control. An experiment was therefore carried out using a lower concentration of FM. Upon labeling using 0.1 mm FM, labeling was seen only in the case of ISO membrane vesicles for both of these mutants (Fig. 3). This indicated that both positions 71 and 266 were cytoplasmic. The localization of these positions was further confirmed by a protection experiment. In the protection experiment, vesicles were preincubated with a low concentration of a more polar maleimide, i.e. 150 μm AMS, before incubation with 1 mm FM. For both V71C and M266C, labeling by FM was inhibited by AMS in only ISO membrane vesicles (Fig. 4). The membrane topology of the a subunit of the F1F0 ATP synthase from Escherichia coli has been probed by surface labeling using 3-(N-maleimidylpropionyl) biocytin. Subunit a has no naturally occurring cysteine residues, allowing unique cysteines to be introduced at the following positions: 8, 24, 27, 69, 89, 128, 131, 172, 176, 196, 238, 241, and 277 (following the COOH-terminal 271 and a hexahistidine tag). None of the single mutations affected the function of the enzyme, as judged by growth on succinate minimal medium. Membrane vesicles with an exposed cytoplasmic surface were prepared using a French pressure cell. Before labeling, the membranes were incubated with or without a highly charged sulfhydryl reagent, 4-acetamido-4′-maleimidylstilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid. After labeling with the less polar biotin maleimide, the samples were solubilized with octyl glucoside/cholate and the subunit a was purified via the oligohistidine at its COOH terminus using immobilized nickel chromatography. The purified samples were electrophoresed and transferred to nitrocellulose for detection by avidin conjugated to alkaline phosphatase. Results indicated cytoplasmic accessibility for residues 69, 172, 176, and 277 and periplasmic accessibility for residues 8, 24, 27, and 131. On the basis of these and earlier results, a transmembrane topology for the subunit a is proposed. The membrane topology of the a subunit of the F1F0 ATP synthase from Escherichia coli has been probed by surface labeling using 3-(N-maleimidylpropionyl) biocytin. Subunit a has no naturally occurring cysteine residues, allowing unique cysteines to be introduced at the following positions: 8, 24, 27, 69, 89, 128, 131, 172, 176, 196, 238, 241, and 277 (following the COOH-terminal 271 and a hexahistidine tag). None of the single mutations affected the function of the enzyme, as judged by growth on succinate minimal medium. Membrane vesicles with an exposed cytoplasmic surface were prepared using a French pressure cell. Before labeling, the membranes were incubated with or without a highly charged sulfhydryl reagent, 4-acetamido-4′-maleimidylstilbene-2,2′-disulfonic acid. After labeling with the less polar biotin maleimide, the samples were solubilized with octyl glucoside/cholate and the subunit a was purified via the oligohistidine at its COOH terminus using immobilized nickel chromatography. The purified samples were electrophoresed and transferred to nitrocellulose for detection by avidin conjugated to alkaline phosphatase. Results indicated cytoplasmic accessibility for residues 69, 172, 176, and 277 and periplasmic accessibility for residues 8, 24, 27, and 131. On the basis of these and earlier results, a transmembrane topology for the subunit a is proposed. The F1F0 ATP synthase fromEscherichia coli is typical of the ATP synthases found in mitochondria, chloroplasts, and many other bacteria (for recent reviews, see Refs. 1Boyer P.D. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1997; 66: 717-749Crossref PubMed Scopus (1554) Google Scholar, 2Capaldi R.A. Aggeler R. Turina P. Wilkens S. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 284-289Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 3Deckers-Hebestreit G. Altendorf K. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1996; 50: 791-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 4Weber J. Senior A.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1319: 19-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (394) Google Scholar). It comprises an F1 complex, which contains the nucleotide-binding subunits involved in catalysis, and an F0 complex, which conducts protons across the membrane. The enzyme from E. coli appears to be a minimal form of the ATP synthase, with eight essential subunits. Five different subunits are found in F1: α, β, γ, δ, and ε, in a stoichiometry of 3:3:1:1:1. Three different subunits, named a, b, and c form F0 with a likely stoichiometry of 1:2:9–12 (5Foster D.L. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 2009-2015Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The mechanism by which an electrochemical proton gradient across the membrane drives ATP synthesis is slowly emerging (6Junge W. Lill H. Engelbrecht S. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 420-423Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar), due in large part to success in recent years in obtaining structural information about the subunits of the enzyme. The crystallization of F1 from bovine mitochondria (7Abrahams J.P. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2719) Google Scholar) led to a high resolution structure of the α3β3 hexamer, plus parts of γ in the central core. Electron cryomicroscopic images have also contributed to an understanding of subunit arrangement (8Gogol E.P. Lucken U. Bork T. Capaldi R.A. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 4709-4716Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 9Gogol E.P. Aggeler R. Sagermann M. Capaldi R.A. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 4717-4724Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar) and motion in F1 subunits (10Gogol E.P. Johnston E. Aggeler R. Capaldi R.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 9585-9589Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Subsequently, the hypothesis of rotation of γ relative to α3β3 (11Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (910) Google Scholar) has been supported by studies involving engineered disulfide-cross-linking of β to γ (12Duncan T.M. Bulygin V.V. Zhou Y. Hutcheon M.L. Cross R.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 10964-10968Crossref PubMed Scopus (456) Google Scholar), a fluorescence technique termed “polarized absorption recovery after photobleaching” (13Sabbert D. Engelbrecht S. Junge W. Nature. 1996; 381: 623-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (459) Google Scholar), and direct visualization of rotation of fluorescently labeled actin filaments covalently attached to γ (14Noji H. Yasuda R. Yoshida M. Kinosita Jr., K. Nature. 1997; 386: 299-302Crossref PubMed Scopus (1925) Google Scholar). The three-dimensional structures of two other F1 subunits from E. coli have been determined: δ (15Wilkens S. Dunn S.D. Chandler J. Dahlquist F.W. Capaldi R.A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1997; 4: 198-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar) and ε (16Uhlin U. Cox G.B. Guss J.M. Structure. 1997; 5: 1219-1230Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar, 17Wilkens S. Dahlquist F.W. McIntosh L.P. Donaldson L.W. Capaldi R.A. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1995; 2: 961-967Crossref PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar). Both subunits are small, two-domain proteins. The ε subunit binds to γ through its NH2-terminal domain at the “base” of F1(18Dunn S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 7354-7359Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Tang C. Capaldi R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3018-3024Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar) and interacts with α and β subunits through its COOH-terminal domain (20Aggeler R. Haughton M.A. Capaldi R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9185-9191Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 21Dallmann H.G. Flynn T.G. Dunn S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 18953-18960Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Aggeler R. Chicas-Cruz K. Cai S.X. Keana J.F. Capaldi R.A. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 2956-2961Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). Both γ and ε subunits have been cross-linked to c subunits (23Zhang Y. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 24609-24614Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 24Watts S.D. Zhang Y. Fillingame R.H. Capaldi R.A. FEBS Lett. 1995; 368: 235-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). The δ subunit interacts with α and β subunits at the “top” of F1 through its NH2-terminal domain (25Ogilvie I. Aggeler R. Capaldi R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16652-16656Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, 26Lill H. Hensel F. Junge W. Engelbrecht S. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 32737-32742Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar), and probably with b subunits through its COOH-terminal domain (27Sawada K. Kuroda N. Watanabe H. Moritani-Otsuka C. Kanazawa H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30047-30053Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 28Engelbrecht S. Junge W. FEBS Lett. 1997; 414: 485-491Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). The three-dimensional structure of a monomeric subunit c has also been determined by NMR (29Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 12167-12177Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar,30Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 665-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Lack of information about the tertiary and quaternary structure of F0 subunits has limited progress in understanding how F0 translocates protons and how it might drive rotation of γ and ε subunits in F1. The b subunits seem to be embedded in the membrane via a span of hydrophobic amino acids at the NH2 terminus. A truncated, soluble form of subunit b has been shown to be extended and dimeric (31Dunn S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 7630-7636Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). NMR studies of subunit c have confirmed the α-helical hairpin structure of the two predicted transmembrane spans (29Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 12167-12177Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar, 30Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 665-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar) and also details of the essential residue Asp61 and its local environment (32Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1635-1645Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 33Assadi-Porter F.M. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 16186-16193Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Questions remain about the oligomeric structure of subunit c and how it interacts with subunits a and b. Mutagenesis has revealed that in addition to Asp61 of subunit c, three residues in subunit a seem to be important in proton translocation: Arg210, Glu219, and His245 (34Cain B.D. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 10043-10050Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 35Cain B.D. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6606-6612Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36Cain B.D. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 3292-3300Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37Lightowlers R.N. Howitt S.M. Hatch L. Gibson F. Cox G.B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1987; 894: 399-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 38Lightowlers R.N. Howitt S. Hatch L. Gibson F. Cox G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 933: 241-248Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Knowledge of the relative location of these four residues could provide much insight into proton translocation and subunit movements. Subunit a is an extremely hydrophobic protein of 271 amino acids. It cannot be expressed at high levels in E. coli (39von Meyenburg K. Jorgensen B.B. Michelsen O. Sorensen L. McCarthy J.E. EMBO J. 1985; 4: 2357-2363Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar) and has only been purified in the presence of trichloroacetate (40Schneider E. Altendorf K. EMBO J. 1985; 4: 515-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Hydropathy analysis (41Wang S. Vik S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3095-3099Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) according to von Heijne (42von Heijne G. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 225: 487-494Crossref PubMed Scopus (1395) Google Scholar) indicates five “certain” transmembrane spans and one “tentative” span. Because the important residues in subunit a reside in the last two predicted transmembrane spans, and the uncertain span immediately precedes this region, at least two plausible arrangements exist. Such questions of membrane topology can be addressed by gene fusion experiments (43Traxler B. Boyd D. Beckwith J. J. Membr. Biol. 1993; 132: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). In the case of subunit a, two groups (44Bjørbæk C. Foërsom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have used phoA fusions to determine its membrane topology but failed to reach agreement. A more recent study used peptide-directed antibodies against polar regions of subunit a to determine membrane topology (46Yamada H. Moriyama Y. Maeda M. Futai M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 34-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar), but only three of the antibodies provided information. To address the issues of how many transmembrane spans are in subunit a and how they are oriented, we have generated a collection of subunit a mutants, each with a single unique cysteine residue. These mutants can be probed with sulfhydryl reagents in oriented membrane preparations to determine the surface accessibility of different residues. Bacteriol. 1983; 153: 416-422Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It produces an a subunit that is truncated near Pro240 (51Hartzog P.E. Cain B.D. J. Cultures were grown at 37 °C in LB or in minimal A medium supplemented with succinate (0.2%) (52Miller J.H. Experiments in Molecular Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1972: 431-435Google Scholar). Media were also supplemented with chloramphenicol (34 mg/liter) or tetracycline (12.5 mg/liter) as appropriate. Inside out membrane vesicles were made from a 250-ml culture in LB medium grown toA 600 = 1.0. Cells were resuspended in 5 ml of 50 mm Tris-HCl containing 10 mm MgSO4(pH 8.0) and passed through the French press at 14,000 p.s.i. After a low speed spin to remove unbroken cells (7000 × g), the supernatant was centrifuged at 50,000 rpm for 1 h in a Beckman Ti-70 rotor. To prepare stripped membrane vesicles (loss of F1), the vesicles were resuspended in stripping buffer (1 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 0.5 EDTA, and 10% glycerol) and agitated at 4 °C overnight. The next day, the centrifugation was repeated, and the vesicles were resuspended in 200 mmTris-HCl (pH 8.0). For nonstripped vesicles, the samples were resuspended directly in 200 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0). The membrane vesicles were labeled in 200 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), with MPB. The reaction was stopped by adding β-mercaptoethanol to a final concentration of 20 mm. The vesicles were then centrifuged at 50,000 rpm for 45 min and resuspended in the original buffer. Blocking with AMS was done in the same buffer, followed by centrifugation at 50,000 rpm for 45 min. The vesicles were resuspended in the same buffer, and labeled with MPB as described above. After labeling, membrane vesicles were resuspended in 100 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 1.5% octyl glucoside, 0.1% deoxycholate, 0.5% cholate, 10 mmβ-mercaptoethanol, 10 mm imidazole, and 1% Tween 20 (53Schneider E. Altendorf K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 7279-7283Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). The samples were incubated with agitation for 1 h at 4 °C and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm (16,000 × g) for 10 min in a microcentrifuge (1.5 ml). The supernatant was added to 0.4 ml of nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid resin that had been previously equilibrated in the extraction buffer. The mixture was incubated with agitation for 45 min at room temperature, and centrifuged for 30 s at 14,000 rpm. The resin was washed three times with 1 ml of wash buffer, consisting of equal volumes of extraction buffer and 200 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0). Subunit a was eluted by adding 0.25 ml of elution buffer (extraction buffer containing 1 mimidazole). The mixture was incubated at room temperature for 5 min and centrifuged (16,000 × g) for 30 s. The supernatant containing the purified subunit a was collected and stored at −20 °C. Samples of purified subunit a were subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (13% acrylamide) and transferred to nitrocellulose membrane (0.2 μm) using a Trans-Blot apparatus (Bio-Rad) overnight at 16 V. The nitrocellulose membrane was blocked with 5% low fat powdered milk in 20 mm Tris-HCl, 500 mm NaCl, pH 7.5 (TBS) for 1 h and rinsed with TBS/Tween 20 (0.05% Tween 20) three times. For MPB detection, the blocked membrane was incubated with avidin-conjugated alkaline phosphatase for 2 h, rinsed three times in TBS/Tween 20, and developed with 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate and nitro blue tetrazolium according to the manufacturer's instructions. For subunit a detection, the blocked nitrocellulose membrane was incubated at room temperature for 2 h with rabbit anti-a serum, diluted 1:5000. After washing five times with TBS/Tween 20, it was incubated with goat, anti-rabbit IgG-alkaline phosphatase conjugate at a dilution of 1:1000 for 2 h. After another five washings with TBS/Tween 20, color was developed as described above. Unique cysteine residues were introduced into subunit a at the following positions: 8, 24, 27, 69, 89, 128, 131, 172, 176, 196, 238, and 277 (COOH terminus). The resulting plasmids were transformed into RH305 (uncB205) and tested for growth on succinate minimal medium. All grew as well as wild type, but three other mutants grew poorly and were not further analyzed: 169 and two double mutants, 24/27 and 238/241. Everted membrane vesicles were prepared using a French pressure cell from cultures of E. coli cells bearing the unique cysteine mutations. Membranes were reacted with various concentrations of MPB from 10 μm to 1 mm, at temperatures from 0 to 25 °C, and for various lengths of time from 10 min to 1 h. The standard conditions chosen were the mildest under which significant labeling was detectable, to minimize the penetration of the membrane by MPB. The labeling patterns were the same whether or not the membranes were stripped of F1. The standard conditions included reaction at 25 °C for 15 min with 120 μm MPB, either with or without a pretreatment with the blocking reagent AMS under the same conditions. MPB (Fig. 3 A) is somewhat polar but can penetrate membranes at higher concentrations. AMS (Fig. 3 B) is highly charged and is much less able to cross biological membranes. Labeling by MPB that can be blocked completely by pretreatment with AMS is indicative of a cytoplasmic facing residue. Labeling by MPB that cannot be blocked by such AMS treatment is indicative of a residue that is not facing the cytoplasm (54Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 843-848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 55Hagting A. Velde J.V.D. Poolman B. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 6777-6785Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). To detect labeling, the subunit a was extracted from membranes by solubilization with a mixture of detergents (cholate, deoxycholate, and octyl glucoside). The subunit a was partially purified via its oligohistidine using nickel affinity chromatography. The samples were electrophoresed, transferred to nitrocellulose, and probed with avidin-conjugated alkaline phosphatase. Results are presented in Fig. 4 for each of the cysteine mutants. These are representative results of experiments performed at least four times. The labeling experiments were controlled for quantity of subunit a present by loading a second panel of samples and transferring to the same sheet of nitrocellulose. The nitrocellulose was cut in half, and the second panel was probed with anti-a antibody. These results are presented in Fig. 5. Subunit a could be detected for all of the mutants except 277C, which was known to be expressed at low levels. Nevertheless, labeling of 277 was relatively high.Figure 5Immunoblots of purified samples of a subunit. A second loading of each of the samples shown in Fig. 4was carried out in the same polyacrylamide gel and was probed with anti-a antibody, as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Labeling is according to Fig. 4.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The results presented in Fig. 4 A show that the following residues can be both labeled by MPB and blocked completely by AMS, indicating a cytoplasm-facing location: 69, 172, 176, 277. In contrast, residues 8, 24, 27, and 131 can be labeled with MPB but cannot be blocked completely by pretreatment with AMS, indicating a location that does not face the cytoplasm. Other residues, 89, 128, 196, and 238, were not labeled at all under these conditions (data not shown). In Fig. 4 B, these residues were treated with higher concentrations of MPB, but little if any labeling was detected. In Fig. 5, it can be seen that of the residues that label very poorly, only 196C and 238C seem to be present at lower levels. The membrane topology of subunit a of the F1F0 ATP synthase from E. coli has been investigated previously, using several different experimental approaches (44Bjørbæk C. Foërsom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 46Yamada H. Moriyama Y. Maeda M. Futai M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 34-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). In this study, unique cysteine residues were introduced into subunit a and tested for accessibility to two maleimide reagents of differing water-solubility (54Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 843-848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 55Hagting A. Velde J.V.D. Poolman B. Konings W.N. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 6777-6785Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 56Bayer E.A. Zalia M.G. Wilchek M. Anal. Biochem. 1985; 149: 529-536Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). A simple and reproducible method of preparation of oriented membrane vesicles was used, and multiple sites were probed in each region of subunit a. The results indicated that residues 69, 172, 176, and 277 (COOH terminus) are accessible to the cytoplasmic face, because they can be labeled by MPB, and this labeling can be blocked completely by AMS. Among these sites, a great range of reactivity exists, indicating greater exposure of residues 69 and 277 than the region of 172 and 176. Also, nearby residues, 89 and 196, were even more resistant to labeling. The labeling pattern of residues 8, 24, 27, and 131 suggests a periplasmic location for these residues, because although they are labeled by MPB, blocking by AMS was not complete. Again, there is a wide range of reactivity from the highly labeled residue 8 to the much less labeled 131. Again, a nearby residue, 128, was much more resistant to labeling. Finally, residue 238 could not be labeled at all. Such a result provides no topological information and could occur because of shielding by protein, including subunit b or c. Such interactions are discussed in the accompanying paper (48Vik S.B. Patterson A.R. Antonio B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 273: 16229-16234Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Two previous studies of the membrane topology of subunit a using the alkaline phosphatase gene fusion technique have been reported (44Bjørbæk C. Foërsom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar, 45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Such experiments are complementary to those described here, because high activity of alkaline phosphatase is indicative of a periplasmic location of the site of the fusion. Each of the two studies offered eight-transmembrane span models for subunit a but were largely incompatible with each other. With the results presented here, there is now more direct evidence that several regions are cytoplasmic, and it is possible to bring the models into agreement. One of the decisions to be made in analysis of fusion studies is to determine a threshold activity for assigning periplasmic location. If this value were to be set at 20% of the maximal activity in the results of Bjørbæket al. (44Bjørbæk C. Foërsom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) or at 25% in the results of Lewis et al. (45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) using LB-glucose, the same two periplasmic regions would be established in each study: near residues 116 and 229–241 in the first study (44Bjørbæk C. Foërsom V. Michelsen O. FEBS Lett. 1990; 260: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) and residues 110–132 and 230–246 in the second study (45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Our results support the first periplasmic assignment and are not in conflict with the second. Recent MPB labeling experiments using permeabilized cells support this second periplasmic region. 2T. Wada, J. C. Long, and S. B. Vik, unpublished results. A discrepancy does exist when considering the results of Lewis et al. (45Lewis M.J. Chang J.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10541-10550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), using an LB growth medium lacking glucose. Under those conditions, they found two additional sites of high activity: at residue 200 (28% of maximum) and at the COOH terminus (83% of maximum). Similar results have been seen in other proteins when the site of fusion occurs at a cytoplasmic region without any positively charged residues to anchor COOH-terminal regions of the fusion protein to the cytoplasm (43Traxler B. Boyd D. Beckwith J. J. Membr. Biol. 1993; 132: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). In subunit a, lysine normally occurs at position 203, and at the COOH terminus there are no positively charged residues except the final residue, His271. In general, one might expect to encounter some difficulties when applying the alkaline phosphatase fusion technique to subunit a. It is now known by immunoblot analysis that subunit a is not found in membranes when either subunit b or c is missing (57Hermolin J. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 2815-2817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). More recently, subunit a was discovered to be a specific target of the ftsHprotease (58Akiyama Y. Kihara A. Ito K. FEBS Lett. 1996; 399: 26-28Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Finally, a variety of results has indicated that the COOH-terminal region of subunit a is important in interactions with the other F0 subunits (41Wang S. Vik S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3095-3099Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 48Vik S.B. Patterson A.R. Antonio B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 273: 16229-16234Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 59Fraga D. Hermolin J. Fillingame R.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 2562-2567Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 60Vik S.B. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 8340-8346Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 61Kumamoto C.A. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 10037-10042Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, it is not likely that subunit a fusions missing the COOH terminus will be able to assemble into an F0 complex, and the resulting topology might not be meaningful. The presence of the ftsHprotease adds another variable in interpretations of alkaline phosphatase activity levels of fusions with subunit a. Hydropathy analysis of the sequence of subunit a (41Wang S. Vik S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3095-3099Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 62Vik S.B. Dao N.N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1140: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) reveals five potential transmembrane spans that are scored as “certain” by the method of von Heijne (42von Heijne G. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 225: 487-494Crossref PubMed Scopus (1395) Google Scholar) and one, residues 182–202, that is scored as “tentative.” The labeling results presented here indicate that there should be an even number of transmembrane spans between residues 176 and the COOH terminus. If the region 230–240 is periplasmic, as both alkaline phosphatase fusion studies indicated, then the “tentative” span is likely to be largely on the cytoplasmic surface. The most amino-terminal of the predicted transmembrane spans consists of residues 40–66. The labeling results indicate that residue 69 is cytoplasmic and that residues 8, 24, and 27 may be periplasmic, although seemingly significant levels of MPB labeling were blocked by AMS. The localization of the amino terminus to the periplasm is in disagreement with the results of studies using peptide-generated antibodies (Ref. 46Yamada H. Moriyama Y. Maeda M. Futai M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 34-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar; see also Ref. 3Deckers-Hebestreit G. Altendorf K. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1996; 50: 791-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar). At all other sites, those studies are in agreement with the labeling results presented here. Therefore, it may be useful to consider alternative interpretations. Lewis and Simoni (63Lewis M.J. Simoni R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3482-3489Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) analyzed the effect of a series of small deletions in subunit a on assembly and function. They found that deletions at the amino terminus, residues 2–35, had a great effect on the level of subunit a found in the membrane and also on the alkaline phosphatase activities of fusions made at residue 125. They concluded that the amino terminus is important for targeting subunit a to the cytoplasmic membrane or for insertion of subunit a into the membrane. A sequence alignment of the amino-terminal portion of subunit a fromE. coli and from several closely related organisms is shown in Fig. 6. A conserved region, residues 11–19, has been identified as capable of forming an amphipathic α-helix (62Vik S.B. Dao N.N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1140: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Two possibilities might explain why the amino-terminal residues seem to show accessibility to both sides of the membrane. First, this region might have a function, such as to act as an “intramolecular chaperone” for the folding and membrane assembly of subunit a. As a consequence of this role, it might have increased accessibility on the cytoplasmic surface. Second, the physical properties of this region may lead to artifactual exposure on the cytoplasmic surface during membrane preparation or may in some way contribute to its labeling. Experiments currently under way in our laboratory have demonstrated the accessibility this region of subunit a to the periplasm.2 Finally, a model of the membrane topology of subunit a is presented in Fig. 7, based on results presented here, and also on this reinterpretation of the alkaline phosphatase fusion studies. Transmembrane spans are all modeled as containing 28 residues. This is consistent with the difficulty of labeling many of the residues that have been tested and with hydropathy analysis (41Wang S. Vik S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3095-3099Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 62Vik S.B. Dao N.N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1140: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Furthermore, these long spans would better match the length of the extremely hydrophobic subunits c, which have been shown by NMR analysis to contain similarly long α-helices (30Girvin M.E. Fillingame R.H. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 665-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Extramembranous segments that are modeled as helical are those that were predicted to be amphipathic, surface α-helices (62Vik S.B. Dao N.N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1140: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). The implications of this membrane topology model on the function of F0 are considered in the accompanying paper (48Vik S.B. Patterson A.R. Antonio B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 273: 16229-16234Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) Tat is chemotactic for monocytes and dendritic cells, an activity that could play a key role in the expansion of HIV infection of accessory cells. To date, domains of Tat previously found to interact with cell surface molecules have shown only partial chemotactic activity toward monocytes. Using overlapping Tat peptides, we identify a novel region of Tat with a potent chemotactic activity for monocytes, reaching levels equal to Tat itself. This peptide also provokes monocyte polarization similar to Tat and is able to compete with Tat for induction of monocyte migration. Specific high affinity (k d = 3 × 10−9m) cell surface binding sites on monocyte cell surfaces for this region of Tat are demonstrated. These data indicate that the majority of Tat effects on monocytes are mediated by a novel region in the cysteine-rich and core domains. These domains are highly conserved among different HIV isolates, suggesting an important role in the establishment of HIV infection.
