Self-Associating Systems in the Analytical Ultracentrifuge. Beckman, Fullerton, CA1993: 8Google Scholar). Open table in a new tab For the rapid equilibrium random mechanism of AMPSase (1Stayton M.M. Rudolph F.B. Fromm H.J. Curr. Top. Cell Regul. 1983; 22: 103-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar),k cat represents the breakdown of the quarternary complex of enzyme and substrates to enzyme and products. Thus,k cat for AMPsase is sensitive to the energy changes in the transition state. Kinetic data indicate destabilization of the transition state for the Asp21 → Ala and Arg419 → Leu mutants (k cat falls 20- and 10-fold, respectively, relative to the wild-type enzyme). Thus, the Asp21-Arg419 salt link must stabilize the transition state. As the hydrogen bond between Asp21 and Arg419 is about 13 Å from the bound Mg2+(approximate center of catalysis), the stabilization is necessarily a result of an indirect mechanism. The loss of the Asp21-Arg419 salt link could destabilize interactions between the 40s and 400s loop. Indeed, in the unligated enzyme Arg419 is disordered (15Poland B.W Silva M.M. Serra M.A. Cho Y. Kim K.H. Harris E.M.S. Honzatko R.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25334-25342Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Silva M.M. Poland B.W. Hoffman C.R. Fromm H.J. Honzatko R.B. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 254: 431-446Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar) and the 40s and 400s loop do not interact. In the ligated enzyme, backbone carbonyl 417 hydrogen-bonds with a water molecule, which in turn hydrogen-bonds to backbone carbonyl 42 and the 2′-OH of GDP (17Poland B., W. Fromm H.J. Honzatko R.B. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 264: 1013-1027Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). An alternative mechanism by which the loss of the Asp21-Arg419 salt link could influence the transition state is by way of a small perturbation of the P-loop (residues 8–16). Asp13 is a putative catalytic base (17Poland B., W. Fromm H.J. Honzatko R.B. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 264: 1013-1027Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar,28Kang C. Sun N. Poland B.W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11881-11885Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). A displacement of its side chain by perhaps as little as 0.5 Å could lead to complete inactivation of the synthetase. The interaction of Asp21 with Arg419 could stabilize the position of helix H1, which lies on the C-terminal side of the P-loop. Mutations in the P-loop have only modest effects on KmGTP and no effect on theK m for other substrates (28Kang C. Sun N. Poland B.W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11881-11885Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), consistent with the lack of change in K m values for the Asp21 → Ala mutant. The mutation of Arg419 to leucine has a minor effect on theK m values for IMP and GTP. The increased KmGTP must be a result of a localized change in the 400s loop as the Asp21 mutation has no effect on K m values. The mutation of Arg419 could perturb the stacking of Pro417with the guanine base and hence lead to the increase in KmGTP. Given the observed binding synergism of IMP and GTP (13Wang W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7078-7084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), a reduced GTP interaction should weaken IMP binding. The side chain of Thr42 binds weakly (at best) to the α-phosphoryl group of GTP, yet it is a conserved residue and its mutation to alanine increases K m values by approximately 10-fold. The above phenomenon may be a consequence of the 40s loop, which is in an equilibrium between two conformational states. The “open” conformer predominates in the absence of ligands, whereas the “closed” conformer appears when ligands are bound to the active site. The absence of an appreciable effect onk cat caused by the mutation of Thr42to alanine implies no significant perturbation of the 40s loop in the ligated conformation of the synthetase. If however, the mutation to alanine stabilizes the open conformation of the loop, then ligands must spend a greater fraction of their binding energy to drive the 40s loop to its closed conformation. That the K m values increase for all substrates is a reflection of synergism in substrate binding (13Wang W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7078-7084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Asn38 → Ala and Asn38 → Glu have no influence on K m values but reducek cat by 200- and 30-fold, respectively. Evidently, the interaction between Asn38 and the 5′-phosphate of IMP does not enhance the affinity of IMP for the active site. Instead, the binding energy probably is diverted completely to the stabilization of the transition state. Asn38 belongs to a short element (residues 38–41) that immediately precedes the 40s loop. Within this structural element, the peptide link between residues 40 and 41 undergoes a significant change in conformation (17Poland B., W. Fromm H.J. Honzatko R.B. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 264: 1013-1027Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar) and the α-carbon and side-chain of Asn38 move toward the 5′-phosphate by 1 Å. These small conformational adjustments preceding the 40s loop are probably coupled to the 9-Å movement of the loop itself. Hence, the energy of interaction of Asn38 with the 5′-phosphate of IMP may go to support the conformational change in the 40s loop. The mutation of Asn38 to aspartate presents a far more complex phenomenon. The introduction of a negative charge at position 38 probably elevates KmIMP by charge repulsion. All of the allowable conformations of Asp38 bring its side chain close to the 5′-phosphate of IMP. (In contrast, allowable conformations of Glu38 are possible, which bring about significant separation of the 5′-phosphate and the side chain.) By protonation of Asp38 and/or the 5′-phosphate of IMP, a hydrogen bond is possible in the Asn38 → Asp mutant. Thus, k cat for the mutant at pH 5.6 is restored to wild-type levels, possibly because IMP can again drive the required conformational change in the 40s loop. K m values for the Asn38 → Asp mutant are not restored to wild-type levels at low pH, however, suggesting that a pH-independent mechanism is responsible for the elevatedK m values of the mutant. The wild-type enzyme is predominantly a monomer in the absence of ligands at concentrations used in assays (13Wang W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7078-7084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Furthermore, IMP induces dimerization of the wild-type enzyme at pH 7.7, its interaction with Arg143 of a second monomer being essential in stabilizing the dimer. The mutation of Arg143 to leucine or lysine does not influencek cat, but increases KmIMP 100-fold at pH 7.7, and concomitantly abolishes ligand-induced dimerization at low concentrations of IMP and enzyme (13Wang W. Gorrell A. Honzatko R.B. Fromm H.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 7078-7084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The high KmIMP values for the Asn38 → Asp mutant at pH 7.7 then may reflect the weak interaction of IMP with the mutant as a monomer, rather than the binding of IMP to a mutant dimer. This is supported by the monomer-dimer dissociation constants for Asn38 → Asp with and without ligands. The higher dissociation constant for the Asn38 → Asp in the presence relative to the absence of ligands shows that Asn38 → Asp favors a dimeric state in the absence of ligands. At pH 5.6, IMP may bind to the active site of the mutant as a monoanion, allowing formation of the hydrogen bond with the side chain of Asp38. However, the monoanionic state of IMP may not stabilize sufficiently its interaction with Arg143 of a second subunit. Hence, the affinity for IMP remains low, because the mutant remains a monomer at low pH. The wild-type enzyme, on the other hand, selects the dianion state of IMP from solution at low pH and, as a consequence, dimerizes. Hence, the KmIMP for wild-type enzyme at pH 5.6 reflects the interaction of IMP with a synthetase dimer. AMPsase is rife with ligand-induced changes, which in a broad perspective influence subunit dimerization and/or reorganization of its active site. As a consequence of the coupling of ligand-binding energy to dynamic processes that influence the conformation of loci remote from the active site, residues can bind directly to substrates and have no effect on binding affinity as measured by K m and residues remote from the active site can have substantial effects on the stability of the transition state or the binding affinity of substrates. Such phenomena underscore the pitfalls in using site directed mutations alone in assigning residues to the active site of an enzyme.

Alternative RNA processing of the human fibroblast growth factor receptor-1 transcript results in receptor forms that vary in their affinity for fibroblast growth factor. An alternative RNA processing event involving recognition of the α-exon is deregulated during neoplastic transformation of glial cells. We have previously established a splicing reporter/transfection cell culture model system to identify sequences involved in recognition of this exon. In this study, the system was used to identify two sequence elements that differentially function to regulate splicing of this exon. Exclusion of the α-exon in glioblastoma cells specifically required the downstream intron sequence comprising the 5′-splice site. Replacement or mutation of this sequence increasing complementarity to U1 RNA resulted in enhanced exon recognition in SNB-19 glioblastoma cells. Sequences within the exon were found to be required for α-exon inclusion. Deletion and gain-of-function experiments identified a 69-nucleotide exon sequence that was specifically required for α-exon inclusion. These studies indicate that multiple sequences are required for the regulated recognition of the α-exon.

Recently, we identified the major in vivo phosphorylation site on v-Mos as Ser-56, which is phosphorylated by cyclic AMP dependent protein kinase (PKA). Others have shown that c-Mos phosphorylation at Ser-3 (equivalent to Ser-34 in v-Mos) is important for the interaction of c-Mos with its substrate MEK and for its stability and cytostatic factor activity in eggs. To investigate the role of Ser-56 phosphorylation, we generated site-directed mutants of v-Mos that would mimic phosphorylation in terms of charge at positions 56 and 34. After mutating serine (S) residues with alanine (A) or glutamic acid (E) in different combinations, various v-Mos mutants were expressed in a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro translation system and in COS-1 or NIH/3T3 cells. The effect of mutations on Mos function was evaluated by in vitro protein kinase assays and by the ability of Mos to cause neoplastic transformation of NIH/3T3 cells. The S56E but not the S56A mutation inhibited v-Mos kinase activity suggesting that Ser-56 phosphorylation has an inhibitory role. As predicted from Xenopus c-Mos studies, S34A but not S34E mutation inhibited v-Mos activity. Studies with the double mutants showed that the S56E mutation but not S56A mutation inhibited v-Mos kinase activity of both S34A and S34E mutants. Interestingly, the S56A mutation blocked the inhibitory effect of the S34A mutation on v-Mos kinase suggesting that in c-Mos the corresponding serine (Ser-25) can influence the regulation of c-Mos by Ser-3. Results showing inhibition of v-Mos kinase activity of the S34E mutant by the S56E mutation is significant as it suggests that doubly phosphorylated Mos at these residues would be inactive. Because residues corresponding to both v-Mos Ser-34 and Ser-56 are evolutionarily conserved in c-Mos, the kinase activity of c-Mos during meiosis may also be regulated in the same manner as v-Mos kinase activity. The amino-terminal sequences play an important part in the regulation of kinase activity and stability of the Mos protein. Xenopus Mos is degraded by ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, signals for which reside in the amino-terminal sequences. c-Mos ubiquitination (at lysine 34) requires Pro-2 and an unphosphorylated Ser-3 (27Nishizawa M. Furuno N. Okazaki K. Tanaka H. Ogawa Y. Sagata N. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 4021-4027Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 28Nishizawa M. Okazaki K. Furuno N. Watanabe N. Sagata N. Phosphorylation at Ser-3 by autophosphorylation and possibly by additional, unidentified Ser-3 kinase or kinases contributes to the stabilization (via inhibition of ubiquitination) as well as activation of c-Mos kinase. Ser-3 phosphorylation also enhances the ability of Mos to interact with its substrate MEK by a mechanism not understood at present (29Chen M. Cooper J.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4727-4734Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). In a previous study designed to understand the mechanisms of inhibition of Mos by the cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA), we identified v-Mos residue Ser-56 as the major site of phosphorylationin vivo (30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Ser-56 is phosphorylated by PKA efficientlyin vitro. Co-expression of the recombinant catalytic subunit of PKA as well as treatment of cells with forskolin, an activator of adenyl cyclase, causes an increase in v-Mos phosphorylation at Ser-56. Residues corresponding to v-Mos Ser-56 and Arg-53 are evolutionarily conserved in c-Mos from frog to man, which makes the corresponding serine in c-Mos (Ser-25) a potential target for phosphorylation by PKA. However, we also found that forskolin treatment inhibited an Ala-56 mutant of v-Mos (termed S56A) by phosphorylation at Ser-263 present in the catalytic domain although the S56A mutant was inhibited less than wild-type v-Mos (30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Thus, based on these results the functional significance of phosphorylation at Ser-56 is not well understood. In this report, we studied the role of phosphorylation of v-Mos residues Ser-56 by site-directed mutagenesis. Our results provide strong evidence that a negative charge at position 56 inhibits v-Mos kinase activity. We also investigated the role of phosphorylation of v-Mos residue Ser-34 (equivalent to c-Mos Ser-3) in the regulation of v-Mos kinase. We did not detect Ser-34 phosphorylation possibly because it occurs only in M-phase. However, mutations at position 34 of v-Mos affected v-Mos activity similar to the way the mutations at position 3 affect Xenopus c-Mos activity. The S34A mutation but not the S34E mutation inhibited v-Mos kinase activity. Therefore, we also examined the effect of mutations at position 56 in combination with mutations at position 34. Overall, our results suggest that activation of c-Mos by phosphorylation of Ser-3 during oocyte maturation would also require the lack of phosphorylation of Ser-25. A. 1985; 82: 7894-7898Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Before mutagenesis, the entire v-mos gene was cloned into pBluescript II SK (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Site-directed mutagenesis was carried out by polymerase chain reaction using oligonucleotide primers containing appropriate base substitutions. Mutations were confirmed by DNA sequencing. His-Mos expression construct was prepared by first cloning a v-mos sequence encoding amino acids 32–374 into theXhoI site of pEBVHis C (Invitrogen, San Diego, CA) by polymerase chain reaction. Then, a NcoI-HindIII fragment encoding His-Mos was excised from the pEBVHis c-mosvector and cloned into the XhoI site of pJC119 by blunt-end ligation. Various Mos mutants were cloned by excising wild-typemos sequences from pJC119-His-Mos and inserting theXhoI mos fragments encoding the mutations. The His-Mos protein contains 39 amino acids added at the amino terminus of v-Mos(32–374). These include (His)6 and an enterokinase cleavage site. The sequences immediately adjacent to Mos are N-Ile-Arg-Pro-Arg-Gly-C. Plasmids were transfected into COS-1 cells by the DEAE-dextran method as described (31Hannink M. Donoghue D.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 7894-7898Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). For stable expression in NIH/3T3 cells, cotransfection with the pKJ1 neo vector (32Adra C.N. Boer P.H. McBurney M.W. For in vitro translation of v-Mos mutants, the pBluescript-v-mos plasmids were linearized, and capped RNAs were synthesized using a Cap-Scribe kit (Boehringer Mannheim). Nonradioactive or [35S]cysteine-labeled v-Mos was synthesized in a rabbit reticulocyte lysate system (Promega, Madison, WI) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Quantitation of the relative amount of radioactivity in protein bands was carried out by scanning densitometry of bands on x-ray films or by scintillation counting of excised gel slices. The transforming activity of Mos mutants was assayed by analyzing the ability of stably transfected NIH/3T3 cells to form colonies in soft agar by the standard procedure. Cells (1 × 104) were seeded in 9.6-cm2 wells of 6-well plates in triplicate. After incubation at 37 °C for 14 days, colonies were stained with 0.1%p-iodonitrotetrazolium violet (Sigma) in phosphate-buffered saline (0.6 ml/well) overnight. Then, the excess dye solution was removed, and the colonies were photographed. This study was designed to understand the role of Ser-56 and its phosphorylation in the regulation of v-Mos kinase activity. Phosphorylation of Ser-3 of c-Mos (equivalent to Ser-34 of v-Mos) is known to be important for Mos kinase activity. Here, we provide evidence that a negative charge at position 56 inhibits v-Mos kinase activity and that Ser-56 is required for the inhibitory effect of the S34A mutation on v-Mos kinase to occur. To investigate the possibility that a functional interaction may occur between Ser-34 and Ser-56 in regulating v-Mos function, site-directed mutagenesis was carried out to substitute serine residues with alanine at Ser-34, Ser-56, or both. The mutants so produced were named S34A, S56A, and S34A/S56A, respectively. Based upon the “second codon rule” governing c-Mos degradation, the stabilizing effect of Ser-3 phosphorylation is strictly dependent upon its position with reference to the amino terminus (28Nishizawa M. Okazaki K. Furuno N. Watanabe N. Sagata N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2433-2446Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). However, the stimulation of c-Mos kinase activity and Mos-MEK interaction by a negative charge at position 3 of c-Mos can also be observed when using recombinant Mos proteins that have extra sequences at the NH2 terminus (e.g. MBP-Mos and LexA-Mos) (29Chen M. Cooper J.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4727-4734Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). As mentioned above, v-Mos contains an extra 31 amino acids at the amino terminus of c-Mos. v-Mos residue 2 is Ala and residue 3 is Arg or His in v-Mos encoded by the HT1 or 124 strains of Moloney murine sarcoma virus, respectively. Thus, by analogy with Xenopus c-Mos, a negative charge at position 34 of v-Mos may enhance v-Mos kinase activity and Mos-MEK interaction but may not affect v-Mos stability. v-Mos and its mutants were expressed in COS-1 cells using a vector containing the SV40 late promoter. After transfection, cell extracts were analyzed at 48 h for autokinase activity using immune complexes prepared with anti-v-Mos(37–55) antibodies (Fig. 1 A). We chose to assay Mos activity by an autokinase assay, because it is most sensitive and faithfully reflects the ability of Mos to phosphorylate its substrate MEK (Ref. 30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, see below). As expected from previous c-Mos studies, the S34A mutant of v-Mos had low kinase activity (less than 10% of the wild-type, compare lanes 1 and 3). The S56A mutant had kinase activity comparable with wild-type v-Mos (lanes 1 and 5). Surprisingly, the S34A/S56A double mutant and the S56A mutant exhibited similar kinase activity (lanes 5and 7), suggesting that v-Mos must contain serine or serine phosphate at position 56 for the inhibitory effect of the S34A mutation to be observed. To determine the relative levels of various mutant Mos proteins and their ability to be immunoprecipitated by the antibodies used in kinase assay, we carried out Western immunoblotting and radioimmunoprecipitation. v-Mos and its mutants S34A, S56A, or S34A/S56A were expressed in COS-1 cells. After the transfected COS-1 cells were metabolically labeled with [35S]methionine for 2 h, the v-Mos protein was immunoprecipitated from cell lysates and analyzed by SDS-PAGE (Fig. 1 B). Interestingly, when compared with the wild-type v-Mos, the S34A mutant migrated faster during SDS-PAGE. In contrast, the double mutant S34A/S56A comigrated with the S56A. This may indicate that the S34A mutation is unable to induce a conformational change in the S56A mutant as it does in the wild-type v-Mos. Western immunoblotting and radioimmunoprecipitation results indicated that the protein level of the S34A mutant was 3–5-fold lower than that of the wild-type v-Mos (Fig. 1, B and C). However, this mutation lowered v-Mos protein kinase activity more dramatically (20-fold) indicating the importance of a serine at this position for the catalytic function. It is possible that phosphorylation affects v-Mos activity differently in transiently transfected COS-1 cells and stably transfected NIH/3T3 cells. Transiently transfected cells contain a higher level of v-Mos per cell than stably transfected NIH/3T3 cells, resulting in cytotoxicity (33Papkoff J. Verma I.M. Hunter T. Cell. 1982; 29: 417-426Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). Therefore, to address this question, stably transfected NIH/3T3 cells expressing v-Mos and its mutants (S34A, S56A, or S34A/S56A) were established. The autokinase activity (Fig. 2 A) and protein levels (Fig. 2 B) of v-Mos and its mutants were analyzed as in Fig. 1. The results obtained were similar to those for transiently transfected COS-1 cells. Examination of the protein kinase activity of various v-Mos mutants and their protein levels suggests that the S34A mutation inhibited v-Mos activity in both COS-1 and NIH/3T3 cells. On the other hand, the S56A mutation did not inhibit the kinase activity of v-Mos (Figs. 1 and 2). One concern about our results was the use of one particular antibody in the immune complex protein kinase assays. This is a valid concern because the antigen epitope in v-Mos is in the vicinity of the phosphorylation sites being investigated. The antigen-binding sites of our anti-Mos(37–55) antibody are completely blocked by v-Mos peptides 42–53 or 44–55 but not blocked by v-Mos peptide 37–48. 2N. K. Herzog, B. Singh, and R. B. Arlinghaus, unpublished observations. Thus, the major antigenic epitope or epitopes for this anti-peptide antibody lie between v-Mos amino acids 44 and 53. To address this concern, a 39-amino acid long sequence from the pEBV-His C vector (Invitrogen) that includes (His)6 was fused to v-Mos amino acids 32–374 (equivalent to the entire c-Mos). The His-Mos fusion protein was expressed in COS-1 cells using the SV40 late promoter. Mos autokinase assay was carried out using immune complexes prepared with antibodies against either a sequence outside Mos (Omni-probe antibody, Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA, which is directed against specific vector sequences mapping between the polyhistidine tag and Mos insert sequences) (Fig. 3 A) or v-Mos residues 37–55 (Fig. 3 B). Similar results were obtained using immune complexes prepared with Omni-probe antibody and the anti-Mos(37–55) antibody, suggesting that the results in Figs. 1 and 2were not because of the use of a particular anti-Mos antibody. Equally important, the results were similar to those shown in Fig. 1, suggesting that the mutant phenotype is not dependent upon the presence of the unique 31 amino acids amino-terminal sequence in v-Mos, which is absent in c-Mos. Next, the effect of S56A mutation on the activity of v-Mos containing residues 32–374 was examined. Similar to the results obtained using v-Mos and His-v-Mos(32–374) (Figs. Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3), the S34A mutation inhibited v-Mos(32–374) but not its S56A mutant. v-Mos(32–374) is similar to c-Mos in terms of size and enzyme activity. 3Y. Yang, C. D. Pham, V. Vuyyuru, and B. Singh, unpublished observations. Furthermore,in vitro autophosphorylation patterns of v-Mos(32–374) and c-Mos are identical as are the in vivo phosphorylation patterns of His-v-Mos(32–374) and His-c-Mos.3 Overall, these results suggest that Ser-56 has a similar role in the regulation of both v-Mos and c-Mos. The mechanism by which Ser-56 influences the outcome of the S34A mutation is not understood at present. To understand the role of Ser-56 phosphorylation, we asked whether a negative charge at position 56 would influence v-Mos protein kinase activity. The S56E mutant of v-Mos was generated and expressed in COS-1 cells and in rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro translation system. To determine the relative specific activity of v-Mos kinase, v-Mos protein was quantitated by Western blotting (in case of COS-1 cells) and incorporation of [35S]cysteine during in vitro translation. In both systems, the S56E mutation caused a significant inhibition (more than 90%) of v-Mos protein kinase activity (Fig. 4). To provide further evidence of the inhibitory role of Ser-56 phosphorylation, we employed two strategies to increase PKA activity, addition of purified PKA catalytic subunit to in vitrotranslated v-Mos and forskolin treatment of transfected COS-1 cells (Fig. 5). Both types of treatment inhibited v-Mos kinase as expected from previous studies (30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). In contrast to wild-type v-Mos, the S56A and S56E mutants were not significantly inhibited by treatments that increase PKA activity. Although an increase in PKA activity also causes some additional minor changes in the phosphorylation of v-Mos (30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar), these results are consistent with an inhibitory role of Ser-56 phosphorylation because PKA requires the presence of Ser-56 to execute its inhibitory effects. To determine the consequences of having different combinations of charge at positions 34 and 56 of v-Mos, site-directed mutagenesis was carried out to substitute Ser-34 and Ser-56 with alanine or glutamic acid in different combinations. Alanine and glutamic acid have been shown to mimic unphosphorylated and phosphorylated serine, respectively, to varying degrees in numerous proteins. Various v-Mos mutants were expressed in vitro in the rabbit reticulocyte translation system (Fig. 6) and in vivo transiently in COS-1 cells or stably in NIH/3T3 cells (Fig. 7). The protein kinase activity of v-Mos mutants was determined by measuring autophosphorylation (Figs. 6 and 7) and transphosphorylation of its substrate MEK1 (Fig. 6). As expected from previous results (30Yang Y. Herrmann C.H. Arlinghaus R.B. Singh B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 800-809Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar), v-Mos autokinase activity correlated with the ability of v-Mos to phosphorylate its substrate MEK1. The relative level of v-Mos protein was determined by measuring [35S]cysteine incorporation (Fig. 6 B) or by Western blotting (Fig. 7 B). Relative specific activity of v-Mos kinase was calculated from the radioactivity measurements of bands in Figs. 4 and 6 (Table I). The mutations affected v-Mos kinase activity similarly in rabbit reticulocyte lysates and in vivo in COS-1 and NIH/3T3 cells (compare Figs. 6 and 7).Figure 7Effect of various v-Mos mutations on Mos kinase from transfected COS-1 and NIH/3T3 cells. As expected from the Xenopus c-Mos studies (28Nishizawa M. Okazaki K. Furuno N. Watanabe N. Sagata N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2433-2446Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 29Chen M. Cooper J.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 4727-4734Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar), activity of the S34E mutant was comparable with that of wild-type v-Mos. The S56E mutation inhibited v-Mos kinase irrespective of the residues at position 34; v-Mos containing either Ser, Ala, or Glu was inhibited by a Glu at position 56 (Figs. 6 and 7). The inhibitory effect of the negative charge at position 56 was dominant over the stimulation effect of the negative charge at position 34. These results suggest that phosphorylation of v-Mos at Ser-56 would render v-Mos incompetent for activation without or with phosphorylation of Ser-34. In contrast to the inhibition by the S56E mutation, the S56A mutation not only did not affect the kinase activity of WT v-Mos, but it also interfered with the ability of the S34A mutant to inhibit v-Mos kinase as described above (Figs. Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3). For some unknown reason, the S56A mutation inhibited activity of the S34E mutant by about 50%. One significant point emerged from the Western blot data shown in Fig. 7 B. There were some reproducible differences in the steady-state protein levels of various Mos mutants. The S34A mutation caused a reduction, and the S34E mutation caused an increase in the amount of v-Mos protein. Although we have not carried out detailed pulse-chase analysis to determine the half-lives of various mutant Mos proteins, these preliminary data indicate that a negative charge at position 34 may stabilize v-Mo
